results.title: Begonia festival
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Boolari Films and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description: At the annual Begonia Festival, Ballarat becomes a city of flowers, music, dancing and drama centred on the famous begonia display. Mr. Tom Beaumont, the curator of the glass house in the Botanic Gardens, tends the many blooms. He is a world authority on begonia culture. Highlights of the display are a thousand double blooms and six hundred distinctive single varieties. In the gardens we see a fine display of salvias, gladioli and dahlias. Young and old admire the wonderful colour and variety of the Botanic Gardens and also the open air art exhibition. Commentary by John Morgan.

results.title: Day at the Show
results.creator_credit: State Film Centre of Victoria and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: A visit to Melbourne’s Royal Show. Commentary designed for children showing the animals, pavilions, motor displays, show bags, fun fair and the grand parade ending with a fireworks display.

results.title: Our friends, why?
results.creator_credit: J. Biss, R. Dudfield and Brighton Grammar School (Vic.). Film Makers Club
results.brief_description: The story revolves around two brothers, their friends and a broken kite. When the friends find out they have been hoaxed by the brothers, there is a rumpus, but finally all shake hands and are friends again. (Award: Best film of all categories at the 1963 Milan International Festival for Young Film Makers)

results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 05
results.brief_description: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew Mackenzie, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The programs style makes the avant-garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Andrew explores Melbourne’s city lane ways, many of which offer public access to street art. He visits City Lights, venue for a a Public Art Project; interviews the author of “Spray Can Art” Jim Prigoff at the Central Station Mural; attends the opening night at Bus Gallery; meets and talks to Mark Amerika at CCP to discuss Amerika’s “Filmtext” (Web Art) Exhibition at the e-Media Gallery and ends the program with an interview with video artist Laresa Kosloff.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 03
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Public hangings”.
‘Public Hangings’ is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avante garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode MacKenzie visits the City of Kingston community arts project in Parkdale, ‘Artbites’. A project where food meets art. James Lynch is interviewed at Uplands Gallery following his recent residency in L.A. and explores themes of the spectacle of images and the relationship with fictitious fantasies. Part 2 of the program features the work of two video artists Dominic Redfern and Daniel Von Sturmer. Introduced by Mackenzie (who provides an entertaining ‘history of video conventions’ in less than 1 minute) are excerpts from Redfern’s ‘Non/un’ and ‘There’s this guy…’ that are concerned with exploring the use of screen surface and space and movement, time and space. Von Sturmer’s work reconstructs the “white cube” to sit within the video frame where he places ordinary objects in order to explore their physical properties, whilst exporting experimental studio processes into video work. The outcome is a surprising observation of the malleability of space and time within the video frame.

results.title: The Visit to Victoria of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II and His Royal Highness the Duke of Edinburgh
results.brief_description: A unique record of an outstanding historical event, the arrival at Essendon Airport on 24 February 1954, of Queen Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh and their subsequent tour of the State of Victoria. Photographed by a large team of professional cameramen, in privileged positions, the film contains such exclusive scenes as the opening of State Parliament and the Royal Command Performance at the Princess Theatre, visits to Hamilton, Benalla, Sale, Traralgon, Yallourn and Mildura; races at Flemington; Flinders Naval Depot; and The University of Melbourne. The film captures all the excitement of the great occasion and shows many interesting sidelights of the Royal progress throughout the State.

results.title: Mining in Action
results.creator_credit: Harold Dews, Cinesound Movietone and Conzinc Riotinto of Australia
results.brief_description: Surveys the development of mining operations of Hammersley Iron and Bougainville copper, the lead/zinc operation of the company and the opening of the aluminium smelter at Bluff, New Zealand.

results.title: Late again
results.creator_credit: Brighton Grammar School (Vic.). Film Makers Club
results.brief_description: A good example of school film making. The boys are late to school again, the master waits with a cane. The attempt to overcome their problems causes the downfall of the master’s wife.

results.title: Hennessy's holiday
results.brief_description: The visit to Melbourne of Hennessy, a 180-pound St. Bernard dog. He sees the Botanical Gardens, the Sidney Myer Music Bowl, and the Shrine, and takes a run around the M.C.G. After intensive grooming he wins a prize at the Royal Melbourne Show, the takes a ride on the “Mightie Mouse” [sic], and he also enjoys a ride on Puffing Billy and a spin on the bay in a speedboat. A modelling appointment, having his portrait drawn by a cartoonist, and an appearance on ‘In Melbourne Tonight’ help make his visit a memorable one for all.

results.title: Click go the shears
results.creator_credit: Jerome Levy, Keith Gow and Link Films
results.brief_description: A highly stylised humorous treatment of the famous Australian ballad, using a minimum of animation. Sung by Cedric McLaughlin and the Link Singers.
